Those cars are some of the HEAVIEST cars ever, lol. Yeah sure, stainless steel lasts a real long time but the quality of the metals used at the factory to build these cars wasn't very good to begin with, and the extreme weight of the car with the relative small engine size, they're not very fast unless you mod them to death, and after that, do you really have a DeLorean, or some kind of Franken-car? And if memory serves, the story of DeLorean ends rather sadly with drug addiction possibly resulting in the inventor's death.

Great Scott!

And it's only because of "Back To The Future" that this otherwise rather unimpressive and underpowered car is worth restoring.

Seriously, the only merit the DeLorean has by itself is its stainless steel body, which is not even a new thing. Stainless steel car bodies date back to the 1930's.

In stock form, it might not even reach 88 MPH because its engine is underpowered and the transmission is weak.
“The DeLorean was manufactured in the 80’s, with doors and panels. The DeLorean was known as a car. These cars are in rough shape, but a restoration can make a DeLorean look like a Restorean.”

I think I've seen three of them, ever.

First time was in the mid 80s, an Air Force Colonel that lived in Bellevue, NE. I worked at an auto parts store and he came in for tail light bulbs. The screws holding the bezels on were rusting!?

The second one I saw was in Kansas City, KS. It was Winter 2016, I was visiting my brother and it was in the parking lot of a shopping mall... evidently being used as a daily driver.

The last one I saw was at an auto show in Omaha, NE just a couple years ago.

My first introduction of the DMC - 12 was in photographs. Sometime around 1981-82, my dad traveled to the hills of California and snapped photos of a DeLorean parked curbside LA. I’ve admired this car ever since, especially the gull-wing doors. Over the years I’ve had the privilege to get close and see this wedge shaped vehicle several times. As I’ve learned more about the man and machine best known as DeLorean, I grew greater respect for his contributions to the automobile industry.
